questions.text: Which of the following are features of direct ophthalmoscopy? Erect, virtual image is formed 2.5x magnification Large field of view Peripheral retinal lesions can be examined Routine fundus examination Semi-dark room required
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Direct Ophthalmoscopy

Indirect Ophthalmoscopy

Image of ophthalmoscope

Image Characteristics

Erect, virtual

Real, inverted

Magnification

About 15x (more in myopes, less in hypermetropes)

About 2.5x with a +20D lens, smaller with stronger lenses

Field of View

Limited, detailed central retina examination

Larger field of view

Uses

Routine fundus examination

Essential for assessing retinal detachment and peripheral retinal lesions

Prerequisites

Semi-darkroom

Darkroom, dilated pupils, convex lens (+20D), binocular ophthalmoscope

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the procedure shown below except

options.label: A
options.text: It's an objective method for refraction testing

options.label: B
options.text: Red reflex moving with the movement of this instrument implies Hypermetropia

options.label: C
options.text: Results are unreliable if the patient’s accommodation is active

options.label: D
options.text: Cycloplegics are only indicated for children below 5 years of age

questions.correct_answer: D. Cycloplegics are only indicated for children below 5 years of age
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Also known as skiascopy or shadow test
  • Objective method to assess refractive errors (Option A)

Principle
  • The direction of the reflected light traveling over the pupil depends upon the refractive state of the eye

Types of Retinoscopes

Mirror retinoscope:

  • Plane (used commonly)
  • Concave (in hazy media and high ametropia)

Self-illuminated retinoscope:

  • Spot
  • Streak retinoscope (more sensitive)
  • Wet retinoscopy: used with cycloplegics
  • Dry retinoscopy: without cycloplegics
  • Static retinoscopy: No active accommodation
  • Dynamic retinoscopy: Performed with active accommodation

Procedure
  • The patient sits 1 meter from the examiner and light is reflected onto the eye.
  • The examiner observes the red reflex and notes its movement in horizontal and vertical meridians.

Cycloplegics
  • Cycloplegics can be used in any age group if active accommodation is present. (Option D)

Commonly used cycloplegics:

  • Atropine: used in < 5 years age, Homatropine: 5-25 years
  • Phenylephrine (Mydriatic) in elderly

Observations
  • With movement: Emmetropia or hypermetropia (Option B)
  • Against movement: Myopia >1D
  • No movement: Myopia 1D

 

Difficulties in Retinoscopy
  • Poor red reflex (small pupil, hazy media, high ametropia)
  • Active accommodation (eliminated by cycloplegia) (Option C)
  • Scissor or conflicting shadows

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of difficulty in reading newspapers and books. Which among the following statements is inappropriate regarding the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Roughly +1D convex lenses can be prescribed

options.label: B
options.text: Coexisting refractive error (myopia/hypermetropia) should be corrected first

options.label: C
options.text: 1.25% Pilocarpine can be beneficial in treatment

questions.correct_answer: A. Roughly +1D convex lenses can be prescribed
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • Physiological insufficiency of accommodation is typically associated with aging.

Etio - Pathogenesis

Age-related factors:

  • Decreased elasticity of the lens capsule.
  • Sclerosis of the lens.
  • Possible decline in ciliary muscle power.

Premature causes:

  • Uncorrected hypermetropia
  • Chronic glaucoma

Symptoms
  • Difficulty in near vision
  • Asthenopic symptoms (eye fatigue)
  • Intermittent diplopia

Treatment Options

Optical Treatment:

  • Convex glasses based on age
  • Correct refractive error for distance first (Option B)
  • Types of Glasses: Unifocal, bifocal, or progressive (varifocal).

Pharmacological therapy:1.25% Pilocarpine(FDA-approved) (Option C)

Surgical options:

  • Conductive keratoplasty (Option D)
  • LASIK (Monovision/presbyopic multifocal-LASIK)
  • Corneal inlays
  • Multifocal IOL placement following lens extraction

40 years

+1.00D

45 years

+1.50D

50 years

+2.00D (Option D)

55 years

+2.25D

60 years

+2.50D

questions.text: All of the following are changes not related to accommodation except

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior lens curvature almost remains the same

questions.explanation:
Definition
  • The mechanism by which the eye increases the power of the crystalline lens to focus on near objects, allowing diverging rays to be focused on the retina.

Changes
  • The curvature of the anterior surface of the lens increases (Option A)
  • Posterior surface curvature almost remains the same (Option B)
  • Contraction of the ciliary muscle ( Option D)
  • Relaxation of zonules (Option C) secondary to ciliary muscle contraction (Helmholtz’s capsular theory)

Far Point (Punctum Remotum)
  • Emmetropic eye - the far point is at infinity
  • Hypermetropic eye - behind the eye
  • Myopic eye - in front of the eye

Near Point (Punctum Proximum)
  • Increases with age

Range of Accommodation
  • The distance between the far point and the near point.

Amplitude of Accommodation
  • The difference in dioptric power needed to focus between the near point (P) and the far point (R).
  • Expressed as A = P - R
  • The amplitude of accommodation decreases with age.

questions.text: A patient post cataract lens extraction refused IOL placement and hence was prescribed spectacles. Later, he presented with complaints of visual discomfort. Choose the right combination of effects the patient would have likely felt. 1) Pincushion effect of distortion 2) Barrel effect of distortion 3) There is magnification of the image 4) There is a minification of the image
questions.explanation:
Pincushion distortion (Statement-1)

Barrel distortion (Statement-2)

There is magnification of the image. (Statement-3)

There is a minification of the image. (Statement-4)

Seen with convex lenses.

Seen with concave lenses.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with blurry vision and difficulty focusing after undergoing cataract surgery 3 weeks ago. On examination, the patient has no lens in the eye and no evidence of intraocular lens (IOL) implantation. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescribe corrective glasses with a high refractive index

options.label: B
options.text: Fit the patient with an intraocular lens

options.label: C
options.text: Perform a keratoplasty to correct vision

questions.correct_answer: B. Fit the patient with an intraocular lens
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • Absence of crystalline lens from the eye.

Aetiology
  • Congenital absence (rare)
  • Surgical removal (common)
  • Traumatic extrusion of lens (rare)
  • Posterior lens dislocation (optical aphakia)

Optical Effects
  • High hypermetropia
  • Reduced eye power to +44 D (from +60 D)

Symptoms
  • Defective vision (far and near)
  • Erythropsia and cyanopsia (abnormal red and blue color defect)

Signs
  • Limbal/corneal scar (in surgical cases)
  • Deep anterior chamber
  • Iridodonesis & Jet-black pupil
  • Only 2 Purkinje images (normal: 4)
  • Hypermetropic small optic disc

Treatment

Correct refractive error with:

  • Spectacles: the problem of spherical aberration and roving ring scotoma (jack-in-the-box phenomenon)
  • Contact lenses
  • Intraocular lenses (IOL) - best method
  • Refractive LASIK surgery

questions.text: In the case of astigmatism, the vertical meridian is more curved than the horizontal. What kind of lens should be given?
questions.explanation:
With-the-Rule Astigmatism (WTR)

Against-the-Rule Astigmatism (ATR)
  • The vertical meridian is more curved than the horizontal.
 
  • Correction requires a concave cylindrical lens at 180° or a convex cylindrical lens at 90°.
 
  • It is called "with-the-rule" because the vertical meridian is normally more convex than the horizontal due to eyelid pressure.
  • The horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian.
 
  • Correction requires a convex cylindrical lens at 180° or a concave cylindrical lens at 90°.

questions.text: A few rays of light are focused on the retina in one meridian and a few others are focused in front of the retina in another meridian. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Regular Astigmatism
  • Refractive power changes uniformly from one meridian to another. There are 2 principal meridians.
  • Oblique Astigmatism- two principal meridians are not horizontal and vertical but are at right angles to each other (e.g., 45° and 135°).
  • Bioblique Astigmatism- two principal meridians are not at right angles to each other (e.g., one at 30° and the other at 100°).

Irregular Astigmatism
  • Irregular change in refractive power in different meridians, with multiple meridians that do not admit geometrical analysis

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with difficulty focusing on both near and distant objects. Examination reveals high hypermetropia. What is the expected fundoscopy finding
questions.explanation:
Type of Hypermetropia

Cause

Axial Hypermetropia

Shortening of the eyeball's axial length. Commonest form.

Curvatural Hypermetropia

Flatter curvature of the cornea, lens, or both.

Index Hypermetropia

Decreased refractive index of the lens, usually due to cortical sclerosis in old age or in treated diabetics.

Positional Hypermetropia

Posterior displacement of the crystalline lens.

Aphakia

Absence of the crystalline lens, either congenital or acquired (e.g., after surgery), leads to high hypermetropia.

Consecutive Hypermetropia

Overcorrected myopia after refractive surgery (e.g., LASIK, ICL) or underpowered intraocular lens (IOL) after cataract surgery.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with gradually worsening blurry vision over the past year with recent improvement in his near vision . On examination, the lens shows yellowish discolouration with increased opacity, consistent with nuclear sclerosis. What kind of myopia has he developed secondary to this?
questions.explanation:
Type of Myopia

Cause

Axial Myopia (Option A)

Increase in the anteroposterior length of the eyeball (most common form).

Curvatural Myopia (Option B)

Increased curvature of the cornea, lens, or both.

Positional Myopia (Option D)

Anterior placement of the crystalline lens in the eye.

Index Myopia

(Option C)

Increase in the refractive index of the crystalline lens, often due to nuclear sclerosis.

Myopia due to Excessive Accommodation

Caused by spasm of accommodation, leading to excessive focusing power.

Clinical features

  • Difficulty with far vision.
  • Half-shutting of eyes for better clarity.
  • Prominent eyeball.
  • Prominent, large, and somewhat sluggishly reacting pupils.
  • Slightly deeper anterior chamber.
  • Normal fundus; rarely a temporal myopic crescent may be seen.

Treatment
  • Prescription of appropriate concave lenses.
  • Surgical Treatment.

questions.text: Identify X:
questions.explanation:
Optic Axis

Passes through the center of the cornea (P), center of the lens (N), and meets the retina (R) on the nasal side of the fovea.

Visual Axis

Line joining the fixation point (O), nodal point (N), and the fovea (F).

Fixation Axis

Line joining the fixation point (O) and the center of rotation of the eye (C).

Angle Alpha (Option A)
  • Angle ANO is formed between the optic axis (AR) and visual axis (OF) at the nodal point (N).

Angle Gamma (Option C)
  • Angle ACO is formed between the optic axis (AR) and fixation axis (OC) at the center of rotation (C).

Angle Kappa (Option D)
  • Angle OPA formed between the visual axis (OF) and pupillary line (AP).
  • The center of the cornea (P) is considered equivalent to the center of the pupil.
  • Clinical significance:
    • Positive angle kappa causes pseudo-exotropia.
    • Negative angle kappa causes pseudo-esotropia.

questions.text: Snellen chart is used to assess which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Snellen’s chart
  • Measures visual acuity by assessing the eye's ability to distinguish details or separate points.

 
  • Rows of decreasing-sized letters fit within squares. Each letter subtends an angle of 5 minutes, and the lines forming letters subtend 1 minute of arc.


 

Visual Acuity Notation
  • Snellen Fraction: Denoted as a fraction, with the numerator being 6 meters and the denominator indicating the distance at which normal vision reads the same letter (e.g., 6/18 means the patient reads at 6 meters what normal vision reads at 18 meters).
  • Metric/Imperial: 6/6 = 20/20 vision.
  • Decimal Acuity: 6/6 equals 1.0 decimal acuity.

Testing Procedure

The patient is positioned 6 meters from the chart, and each eye is tested individually, starting with the right eye. The patient reads the smallest visible letter.

Limitations
  • Refractive Errors: Primarily measures uncorrected vision. Pinhole tests help detect refractive errors that can be corrected with lenses.
  • Subjectivity: Dependent on patient literacy, language, and cognitive ability.
  • Scope: Assesses only visual acuity, not contrast sensitivity, color vision, or peripheral vision.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with a mature cataract presents for an eye examination. During the assessment, the ophthalmologist observes the absence of a specific Purkinje image. Which Purkinje image is most likely to be absent in this case?
Which of the following is the most sensitive test for both congenital and acquired colour vision defects?

A 40-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of painful vision loss in her right eye. She has a history of multiple sclerosis. On examination, her visual acuity is 20/30 in the right eye, and a RAPD is noted. She reports difficulty distinguishing red and green colors in the right eye, but her left eye is normal on color vision testing. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her acquired color blindness?
Which type of colour blindness is caused by the absence of green cones in the retina?
questions.explanation:
Trichromatic colour vision

Dichromatic colour vision

Monochromatic colour vision

The mechanism to appreciate all three primary colours is present but defective for one or two

One of the three primary colours is completely absent

Either have only one type of cone or total colour blindness.
  • Protanomalous: Defective red colour appreciation.
 
  • Deuteranomalous: Defective green colour appreciation.
 
  • Tritanomalous: Defective blue colour appreciation.
  • Protanopia: Complete red colour defect. (Option A)
 
  • Deuteranopia: Complete green colour defect.
 
  • Tritanopia: Absence of blue colour appreciation. (Option C)
  • Cone monochromatism: Only one type of cone presents with poor day vision and normal night vision.
 
  • Rod monochromatism/ Achromatopsia: Total colour blindness with day blindness.

(Option D)

questions.text: At what age do infants typically begin to perceive and distinguish between different colors?

A 55-year-old male presents with complaints of difficulty driving at night and reading in dim light, despite having normal visual acuity during his eye exam. He underwent cataract surgery six months ago but still experiences these visual issues. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to assess his current visual problem?

A patient’s visual acuity improves significantly when looking through a small, opaque disc with a tiny hole, as shown in the image below. What is the likely cause of this improvement in visual acuity?
questions.explanation:
Pinhole Test

Stenopeic Slit Test

Mechanism

Uses a small opaque disc with holes to reduce retinal blur and improve visual acuity in refractive errors up to 4D.

Uses a narrow slit to reduce peripheral aberrations and enhance depth of focus.

 

Clinical Applications
  • Determines if reduced vision is due to refractive errors; vision improvement suggests a refractive issue. (Option B)
  • Quick assessment of visual acuity, often in under-resourced settings.
  • WHO recommended blindness surveys.
  • To assess astigmatism, especially irregular astigmatism (as it allows for a more detailed analysis of the patient's visual field by focusing light along a single axis) or complex visual issues.
  • A stenopeic slit is used in cases of corneal opacities to help identify the best location for an optical iridectomy.

Limitations
  • Can underestimate post-refractive visual acuity.
  • Reduces light reaching the retina, potentially causing diffraction blur.
  • Limited mainly to complex refractive issues.

questions.text: Match the following visual acuity charts used to assess children of preschool age. 1) Allen test cards a) 2) HOTV test b) 3) Stycar Test c) 4) Cardiff Acuity test d)
questions.explanation:
Visual acuity assessment- preschool

1) Allen test cards

  • Designed for children aged 2 to 4 years.
  • 4 flashcards are used to test containing 7 schematic figures.
  • They are identified from different distances points

a)

2) HOTV test

  • Designed for children older than 4 years.
  • Test involves identifying the letters “H,” “O,” “T,” and “V.”
  • The letters decrease in size from the top to the bottom of the chart.

b)

3) Stycar Test (Screening Test for Young Children and Retarded)

c)

4) Cardiff Acuity card test

  • The Cardiff Acuity Test is a vision assessment tool designed specifically for infants and young children (typically aged 6 months to 3 years) (Option C)
  • Each card has the picture placed at either the top or the bottom.
  • The child is shown a series of cards, and their eye movement is observed to see if they look in the direction of the picture (indicating they’ve seen it).

d)

questions.text: Which among the following is used to check visual acuity in children less than 1 year? 1) 2) 3) 4)
questions.explanation:
1) Cardiff Acuity test

  • The Cardiff Acuity Test is a vision assessment tool designed specifically for infants and young children (typically aged 6 months to 3 years) (Option C)

  • Each card has the picture placed at either the top or the bottom.

  • The child is shown a series of cards, and their eye movement is observed to see if they look in the direction of the picture (indicating they’ve seen it).

2) Tellers chart

  • Utilises infants' natural tendency to look at patterns i.e., it is a preferential Looking Test.
  • Suitable for infants

3) Optokinetic Drum Test (OKN)

  • A rotating striped drum elicits involuntary eye movements.
  • Adjusting the stripe width helps estimate visual acuity, especially for non-verbal children.

4) Visually evoked response test (VER)

  • Measures brain activity in response to visual stimuli

Visual acuity assessment in children of different age groups

Infancy

1 to 2 years

2 to 3 years

3 to 5 years
  • Catford drum test
  • Fixation test
  • OKNOVIS
  • Teller acuity cards (Preferential looking test)
  • Reflex response
  • Visual evoked responses
  • Boeck candy test
  • Sheridan ball test
  • Worth Ivory-ball test
  • Coin test
  • Dot visual acuity test
  • Miniature toys test
  • Landolt C
  • Lea symbols chart
  • Lippman’s HOTV test
  • Sheridan letter test
  • Tumbling E

questions.text: Which among the following is used to check visual acuity in illiterate adults? 1) 2) 3) 4)
questions.explanation:
1) Snellen’s chart

  • Measures visual acuity by assessing the eye's ability to distinguish details or separate points.

2) Tumbling "E" Visual Acuity Chart

 

  • Involves matching the orientation of the letter "E" in different sizes.
  • Used to check visual acuity illiterate. (Option B)

3) LOGMAR chart

  • LOGMAR is a refined method for measuring and expressing visual acuity, offering advantages over the traditional Snellen chart:
    • Precision: LOGMAR charts are more sensitive and allow finer measurements compared to Snellen charts.
    • Tracking Changes: The consistent progression aids in detecting subtle improvements or declines in vision.
    • Reliability: The standardized format and equally legible letters enhance measurement reliability.

4) Landolt's broken ring test

 

The "C" is presented in various directions (top, bottom, left, or right), and the size of the "C" decreases progressively, similar to Snellen charts.

 

Procedure:

  • The individual is shown on the chart from a standardized distance.
  • For each "C" presented, they indicate the direction of the gap (either verbally or by pointing).
  •  
  • The test continues until the individual can no longer accurately determine the gap’s direction.
  • Used to check visual acuity in illiterate. (Option B)

5) Jaeger chart

Gold standard for reading vision tests
